blocks.name: cgz
blocks.content: Extend class notation with the set of gaussian integers.
blocks.origin: const class cgz { Z[i] }

blocks.name: diff.cgz.s
diff.cgz.c
diff.cgz.w
df-gz
blocks.content: Define the set of gaussian integers, which are complex numbers whose real and imaginary parts are integers. (Note that the ` [ _i ] ` is actually part of the symbol token and has no independent meaning.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: elgz
blocks.content: Elementhood in the gaussian integers. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm elgz(class c0) {
  |- wb(wcel(c0, cgz), w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz)))
} = {
  bitr4i(wcel(c0, cgz), w3a(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz)), wa(wcel(c0, cc), wa(wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))))
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgz, cc, wa(wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz)), wa(wcel(cfv(cre, cv(hs0)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, cv(hs0)), cz)))
  anbi12d(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wcel(cfv(cre, cv(hs0)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, cv(hs0)), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  eleq1d(cfv(cre, cv(hs0)), cz, cfv(cre, c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c0, cre)
  eleq1d(cfv(cim, cv(hs0)), cz, cfv(cim, c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c0, cim)
  df-gz(hs0)
  3anass(wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.w(wa(wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz)))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm elgz(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ Z[i]↔(c0 ∈ ℂ ∧(Re ` c0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` c0)∈ ℤ))
} = {
  bitr4i(c0 ∈ Z[i], (c0 ∈ ℂ ∧(Re ` c0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` c0)∈ ℤ), (c0 ∈ ℂ ∧((Re ` c0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)))
  elrab2(hs0, c0, cgz, cc, ((Re ` c0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` c0)∈ ℤ), ((Re ` hs0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` hs0)∈ ℤ))
  anbi12d(hs0 = c0, (Re ` hs0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` hs0)∈ ℤ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  eleq1d((Re ` hs0), cz, (Re ` c0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq2(hs0, c0, cre)
  eleq1d((Im ` hs0), cz, (Im ` c0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq2(hs0, c0, cim)
  df-gz(hs0)
  3anass(c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.w(((Re ` c0)∈ ℤ ∧(Im ` c0)∈ ℤ))
}

blocks.name: gzcn
blocks.content: A gaussian integer is a complex number. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: zgz
blocks.content: An integer is a gaussian integer. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm zgz(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c0, cgz))
} = {
  syl3anbrc(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  zcn(c0)
  eqeltrd(cfv(cre, c0), cz, c0, wcel(c0, cz))
  rered(c0, wcel(c0, cz))
  id(wcel(c0, cz))
  syl6eqel(cfv(cim, c0), cz, nat0, wcel(c0, cz))
  reim0d(c0, wcel(c0, cz))
  zre(c0)
  0z()
  elgz(c0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm zgz(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ ℤ → c0 ∈ Z[i])
} = {
  syl3anbrc(c0 ∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ Z[i], c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  zcn(c0)
  eqeltrd((Re ` c0), cz, c0, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  rered(c0, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  id(c0 ∈ ℤ)
  syl6eqel((Im ` c0), cz, nat0, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  reim0d(c0, c0 ∈ ℤ)
  zre(c0)
  0z()
  elgz(c0)
}

blocks.name: igz
blocks.content: ` _i ` is a gaussian integer. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: gznegcl
blocks.content: The gaussian integers are closed under negation. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gznegcl(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cneg(c0), cgz))
} = {
  syl3anbrc(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cneg(c0), cgz), wcel(cneg(c0), cc), wcel(cfv(cre, cneg(c0)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, cneg(c0)), cz))
  negcld(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cre, cneg(c0)), cz, cneg(cfv(cre, c0)), wcel(c0, cgz))
  renegd(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  znegcld(cfv(cre, c0), wcel(c0, cgz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cim, cneg(c0)), cz, cneg(cfv(cim, c0)), wcel(c0, cgz))
  imnegd(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  gzcn(c0)
  znegcld(cfv(cim, c0), wcel(c0, cgz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))
  elgz(c0)
  elgz(cneg(c0))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm gznegcl(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ Z[i]→ -u(c0)∈ Z[i])
} = {
  syl3anbrc(c0 ∈ Z[i], -u(c0)∈ Z[i], -u(c0)∈ ℂ, (Re ` -u(c0))∈ ℤ, (Im ` -u(c0))∈ ℤ)
  negcld(c0, c0 ∈ Z[i])
  eqeltrd((Re ` -u(c0)), cz, -u((Re ` c0)), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  renegd(c0, c0 ∈ Z[i])
  znegcld((Re ` c0), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  simp2bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  eqeltrd((Im ` -u(c0)), cz, -u((Im ` c0)), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  imnegd(c0, c0 ∈ Z[i])
  gzcn(c0)
  znegcld((Im ` c0), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  simp3bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c0)
  elgz(-u(c0))
}

blocks.name: gzcjcl
blocks.content: The gaussian integers are closed under conjugation. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gzcjcl(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(ccj, c0), cgz))
} = {

  cjcld(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cre, cfv(ccj, c0)), cz, cfv(cre, c0), wcel(c0, cgz))
  recjd(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cim, cfv(ccj, c0)), cz, cneg(cfv(cim, c0)), wcel(c0, cgz))
  imcjd(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  gzcn(c0)
  znegcld(cfv(cim, c0), wcel(c0, cgz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))

blocks.pretty:
thm gzcjcl(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ Z[i]→(* ` c0)∈ Z[i])
} = {
  syl3anbrc(c0 ∈ Z[i], (* ` c0)∈ Z[i], (* ` c0)∈ ℂ, (Re `(* ` c0))∈ ℤ, (Im `(* ` c0))∈ ℤ)

  imcjd(c0, c0 ∈ Z[i])
  gzcn(c0)
  znegcld((Im ` c0), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  simp3bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c0)
  elgz((* ` c0))
}

blocks.name: gzaddcl
blocks.content: The gaussian integers are closed under addition. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gzaddcl(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)), wcel(co(c0, caddc, c1), cgz))
} = {
  syl3anbrc(wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)), wcel(co(c0, caddc, c1), cgz), wcel(co(c0, caddc, c1), cc), wcel(cfv(cre, co(c0, caddc, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, co(c0, caddc, c1)), cz))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(c0, caddc, c1), cc), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  addcl(c0, c1)
  eqeltrd(cfv(cre, co(c0, caddc, c1)), cz, co(cfv(cre, c0), caddc, cfv(cre, c1)), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wceq(cfv(cre, co(c0, caddc, c1)), co(cfv(cre, c0), caddc, cfv(cre, c1))), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  readd(c0, c1)
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cre, c0), caddc, cfv(cre, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz))
  zaddcl(cfv(cre, c0), cfv(cre, c1))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cim, co(c0, caddc, c1)), cz, co(cfv(cim, c0), caddc, cfv(cim, c1)), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wceq(cfv(cim, co(c0, caddc, c1)), co(cfv(cim, c0), caddc, cfv(cim, c1))), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  gzcn(c0)
  gzcn(c1)
  imadd(c0, c1)
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cim, c0), caddc, cfv(cim, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))
  elgz(c0)
  simp3bi(wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz))
  elgz(c1)
  zaddcl(cfv(cim, c0), cfv(cim, c1))
  elgz(co(c0, caddc, c1))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm gzaddcl(class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i])→(c0[+]c1)∈ Z[i])
} = {
  syl3anbrc((c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]), (c0[+]c1)∈ Z[i], (c0[+]c1)∈ ℂ, (Re `(c0[+]c1))∈ ℤ, (Im `(c0[+]c1))∈ ℤ)
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (c0[+]c1)∈ ℂ, c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  addcl(c0, c1)
  eqeltrd((Re `(c0[+]c1)), cz, ((Re ` c0)[+](Re ` c1)), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (Re `(c0[+]c1))=((Re ` c0)[+](Re ` c1)), c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  readd(c0, c1)
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Re ` c0)[+](Re ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  simp2bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  simp2bi(c1 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  zaddcl((Re ` c0), (Re ` c1))
  eqeltrd((Im `(c0[+]c1)), cz, ((Im ` c0)[+](Im ` c1)), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (Im `(c0[+]c1))=((Im ` c0)[+](Im ` c1)), c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  gzcn(c0)
  gzcn(c1)
  imadd(c0, c1)
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Im ` c0)[+](Im ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  simp3bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c0)
  simp3bi(c1 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c1)
  zaddcl((Im ` c0), (Im ` c1))
  elgz((c0[+]c1))
}

blocks.name: gzmulcl
blocks.content: The gaussian integers are closed under multiplication. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gzmulcl(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cgz))
} = {
  syl3anbrc(wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cgz), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cc), wcel(cfv(cre, co(c0, cmul, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, co(c0, cmul, c1)), cz))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cc), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  mulcl(c0, c1)
  eqeltrd(cfv(cre, co(c0, cmul, c1)), cz, co(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), cmin, co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1))), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wceq(cfv(cre, co(c0, cmul, c1)), co(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), cmin, co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)))), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  remul(c0, c1)
  zsubcld(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz))
  zmulcl(cfv(cre, c0), cfv(cre, c1))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz))
  zmulcl(cfv(cim, c0), cfv(cim, c1))
  eqeltrd(cfv(cim, co(c0, cmul, c1)), cz, co(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), caddc, co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1))), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wceq(cfv(cim, co(c0, cmul, c1)), co(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), caddc, co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)))), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  gzcn(c0)
  gzcn(c1)
  immul(c0, c1)
  zaddcld(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), wa(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cre, c0), cmul, cfv(cim, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz))
  zmulcl(cfv(cre, c0), cfv(cim, c1))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cim, c0), cmul, cfv(cre, c1)), cz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))
  elgz(c0)
  simp2bi(wcel(c1, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c1), cz), wcel(c1, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c1), cz))
  elgz(c1)
  zmulcl(cfv(cim, c0), cfv(cre, c1))
  elgz(co(c0, cmul, c1))
}

thm gzmulcl(class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i])→(c0[×]c1)∈ Z[i])
} = {
  syl3anbrc((c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]), (c0[×]c1)∈ Z[i], (c0[×]c1)∈ ℂ, (Re `(c0[×]c1))∈ ℤ, (Im `(c0[×]c1))∈ ℤ)
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (c0[×]c1)∈ ℂ, c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  mulcl(c0, c1)
  eqeltrd((Re `(c0[×]c1)), cz, (((Re ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))[-]((Im ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (Re `(c0[×]c1))=(((Re ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))[-]((Im ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))), c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  remul(c0, c1)
  zsubcld(((Re ` c0)[×](Re ` c1)), ((Im ` c0)[×](Im ` c1)), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Re ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  zmulcl((Re ` c0), (Re ` c1))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Im ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  zmulcl((Im ` c0), (Im ` c1))
  eqeltrd((Im `(c0[×]c1)), cz, (((Re ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))[+]((Im ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], (Im `(c0[×]c1))=(((Re ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))[+]((Im ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))), c0 ∈ ℂ, c1 ∈ ℂ)
  gzcn(c0)
  gzcn(c1)
  immul(c0, c1)
  zaddcld(((Re ` c0)[×](Im ` c1)), ((Im ` c0)[×](Re ` c1)), (c0 ∈ Z[i]∧ c1 ∈ Z[i]))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Re ` c0)[×](Im ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  simp2bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  simp3bi(c1 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  zmulcl((Re ` c0), (Im ` c1))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ Z[i], c1 ∈ Z[i], ((Im ` c0)[×](Re ` c1))∈ ℤ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  simp3bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c0)
  simp2bi(c1 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c1)∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  elgz(c1)
  zmulcl((Im ` c0), (Re ` c1))
  elgz((c0[×]c1))
}

blocks.name: gzreim
blocks.content: Construct a gaussian integer from real and imaginary parts. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 16-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: gzsubcl
blocks.content: The gaussian integers are closed under subtraction. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: gzabssqcl
blocks.content: The squared norm of a gaussian integer is an integer. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 16-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gzabssqcl(class c0) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cabs, c0), cexp, nat2), cn0))
} = {
  eqeltrd(co(cfv(cabs, c0), cexp, nat2), cn0, co(co(cfv(cre, c0), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cfv(cim, c0), cexp, nat2)), wcel(c0, cgz))
  absvalsq2d(c0, wcel(c0, cgz))
  gzcn(c0)
  nn0addcld(co(cfv(cre, c0), cexp, nat2), co(cfv(cim, c0), cexp, nat2), wcel(c0, cgz))
  syl(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cre, c0), cexp, nat2), cn0), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))
  simp2bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  zsqcl2(cfv(cre, c0))
  syl(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(co(cfv(cim, c0), cexp, nat2), cn0), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz))
  simp3bi(wcel(c0, cgz), wcel(cfv(cim, c0), cz), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(cfv(cre, c0), cz))
  elgz(c0)
  zsqcl2(cfv(cim, c0))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm gzabssqcl(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ Z[i]→((abs ` c0)[^]2)∈ ℕ0)
} = {
  eqeltrd(((abs ` c0)[^]2), cn0, (((Re ` c0)[^]2)[+]((Im ` c0)[^]2)), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  absvalsq2d(c0, c0 ∈ Z[i])

  nn0addcld(((Re ` c0)[^]2), ((Im ` c0)[^]2), c0 ∈ Z[i])
  syl(c0 ∈ Z[i], ((Re ` c0)[^]2)∈ ℕ0, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  simp2bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  zsqcl2((Re ` c0))
  syl(c0 ∈ Z[i], ((Im ` c0)[^]2)∈ ℕ0, (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ)
  simp3bi(c0 ∈ Z[i], (Im ` c0)∈ ℤ, c0 ∈ ℂ, (Re ` c0)∈ ℤ)

thm 4sqlem5(class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {

} = {
  jca(w0, wcel(c0, cz), wcel(co(co(c1, cmin, c0), cdiv, c2), cz))

  zsubcld(c1, co(c1, cmin, c0), w0)

  syl5eqel(c0, cc, co(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), cmin, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), w0)
  subcld(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), co(c2, cdiv, nat2), w0)
  recnd(c2, w0)
  nnne0d(c2, w0)
  zmulcld(co(co(c1, cmin, c0), cdiv, c2), c2, w0)
  nnzd(c2, w0)
  eqeltrd(co(co(c1, cmin, c0), cdiv, c2), cz, co(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmin, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2)), cdiv, c2), w0)
  oveq1d(co(c1, cmin, c0), cdiv, c2, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmin, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2)), w0)
  syl5eq(co(c1, cmin, c0), co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmin, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2)), co(c1, cmin, co(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), cmin, co(c2, cdiv, nat2))), w0)
  oveq2i(c1, cmin, c0, co(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), cmin, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)))
  subsub3d(c1, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), co(c2, cdiv, nat2), w0)
  zcnd(c1, w0)
  recnd(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2), w0)
  modcld(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), c2, w0)
  recnd(co(c2, cdiv, nat2), w0)
  syl2anc(w0, wcel(co(co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmin, co(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c2)), cdiv, c2), cz), wcel(co(c1, caddc, co(c2, cdiv, nat2)), cr), wcel(c2, crp))
  readdcld(c1, co(c2, cdiv, nat2), w0)
  zred(c1, w0)
  rehalfcld(c2, w0)
  nnred(c2, w0)
  nnrpd(c2, w0)

thm 4sqlem6(class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {

  modge0(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), c0)

  syl5eqbr(c1, clt, co(c0, cdiv, nat2), co(co(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c0), cmin, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), w0)
  mpbird(w0, wbr(co(co(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c0), cmin, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), clt, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), wbr(co(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c0), clt, co(co(c0, cdiv, nat2), caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2))))

  syl2anc(w0, wbr(co(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c0), clt, c0), wcel(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cr), wcel(c0, crp))
  modlt(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), c0)
  2halvesd(c0, w0)
  nncnd(c0, w0)
  ltsubaddd(co(co(c2, caddc, co(c0, cdiv, nat2)), cmo, c0), co(c0, cdiv, nat2), co(c0, cdiv, nat2), w0)

thm 4sqlem9(class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0, wff w1) {

  sqeq0(c2)

  adantr(w0, w1, wcel(co(co(c1, cmin, c2), cdiv, c0), cz))
  simprd(w0, wcel(co(co(c1, cmin, c2), cdiv, c0), cz), wcel(c2, cz))
  4sqlem5(c2, c1, c0, w0)

blocks.name: 4sqlem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ 4sq . The set ` S ` is the set of all numbers that are expressible as a sum of four squares. Our goal is to show that ` S = NN0 ` ; here we show one subset direction. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:

  -| diffss(s0, s1)

  -| diffss(s1, s4)

  rexlimivv(s1, s2, cz, cz, wrex(s3, cz, wrex(s4, cz, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s2), cexp, nat2)), caddc, co(co(cv(s3), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s4), cexp, nat2)))))), wcel(cv(s0), cn0))

blocks.name: mul4sqlem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ mul4sq : algebraic manipulations. The extra assumptions involving ` M ` are for a part of ~ 4sqlem17 which needs to know not just that the product is a sum of squares, but also that it preserves divisibility by ` M ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm mul4sqlem(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wcel(co(co(c0, cdiv, c1), cmul, co(c2, cdiv, c1)), c3))
  -| wceq(c3, cab(s0, wrex(s1, cz, wrex(s2, cz, wrex(s3, cz, wrex(s4, cz, wceq(cv(s0), co(co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s2), cexp, nat2)), caddc, co(co(cv(s3), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s4), cexp, nat2))))))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c4, cgz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c5, cgz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c6, cgz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c7, cgz))
  -| wceq(c0, co(co(cfv(cabs, c4), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cfv(cabs, c5), cexp, nat2)))
  -| wceq(c2, co(co(cfv(cabs, c6), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cfv(cabs, c7), cexp, nat2)))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cn))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(co(co(c4, cmin, c6), cdiv, c1), cgz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(co(co(c5, cmin, c7), cdiv, c1), cgz))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(co(c0, cdiv, c1), cn0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)

blocks.name: mul4sq
blocks.content: Euler's four-square identity: The product of two sums of four squares is also a sum of four squares. This is usually quoted as an explicit formula involving eight real variables; we save some time by working with complex numbers (gaussian integers) instead, so that we only have to work with four variables, and also hiding the actual formula for the product in the proof of ~ mul4sqlem . (For the curious, the explicit formula that is used is ` ( | a | ^ 2 + | b | ^ 2 ) ( | c | ^ 2 + | d | ^ 2 ) = ` ` | a * x. c + b x. d * | ^ 2 + | a * x. d - b x. c * | ^ 2 ` .) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: 4sqlem11
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ 4sq . Use the pigeonhole principle to show that the sets ` { m ^ 2 | m e. ( 0 ... N ) } ` and ` { -u 1 - n ^ 2 | n e. ( 0 ... N ) } ` have a common element, ` mod P ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 15-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: 4sqlem12
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ 4sq . For any odd prime ` P ` , there is a ` k < P ` such that ` k P - 1 ` is a sum of two squares. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 15-Jul-2014.)

blocks.name: 4sqlem19
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ 4sq . The proof is by strong induction - we show that if all the integers less than ` k ` are in ` S ` , then ` k ` is as well. In this part of the proof we do the induction argument and dispense with all the cases except the odd prime case, which is sent to ~ 4sqlem18 . If ` k ` is ` 0 , 1 , 2 ` , we show ` k e. S ` directly; otherwise if ` k ` is composite, ` k ` is the product of two numbers less than it (and hence in ` S ` by assumption), so by ~ mul4sq ` k e. S ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Jul-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 20-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: 4sq
blocks.content: Lagrange's four-square theorem, or Bachet's conjecture: every nonnegative integer is expressible as a sum of four squares. This is Metamath 100 proof #19. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 16-Jul-2014.)
